revision.text:
{{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}} {{Infobox person | image = Carlos Mencia hat.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Mencia prior to a live concert at a U.S. Army camp in the Persian Gulf Region | birthname = Ned Arnel Mencía | alias = Ned Holness<ref name="Menciastories"/> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1967|10|22}} | birth_place = [[San Pedro Sula]], [[Honduras]] | occupation = Actor, comedian, writer | yearsactive = 1990–present }}
'''Carlos Mencia''' (born October 22, 1967), born '''Ned Arnel Mencia''', is a [[Honduras|Honduran-born]] American [[comedian]], writer, and actor. His style of comedy is often political and involves issues of [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[culture]], [[criminal justice]], and [[social class]]. He was formerly the host of his own show on [[Comedy Central]], ''[[Mind of Mencia]]''.
==Early life== Mencía was born in [[San Pedro Sula]], [[Honduras]], the seventeenth of eighteen children. His mother, Magdelena Mencía, was [[Mexico|Mexican]], and his father, Roberto Holness, was a [[Honduras|Honduran]] whose distant ancestors included immigrants from [[Germany]], [[England]], and the [[Cayman Islands]].<ref name="nprref2">{{cite news|last=Inskeep|first=Steve|coauthors=|title=Conversations on Immigration: Carlos Mencia|pages=|publisher=NPR|date=2006-06-12|url=http://m.npr.org/news/front/5478147?singlePage=true|accessdate=2010-03-18}}</ref> At the time of his birth, Mencía's mother engaged in a [[domestic violence|domestic dispute]] with his father, and declined to give her son his biological father's last name.<ref name = "Menciastories">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | year = | url = http://www.carlosmencia.com/oldwebsite/stories.htm | title = October 3rd: the Doghouse Comedy Jam | work = | publisher = CarlosMencia.com | accessdate = 2007-02-02 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070212030042/http://www.carlosmencia.com/oldwebsite/stories.htm |archivedate = February 12, 2007}}</ref><ref name="npref1">{{cite news|last=Adams|first=Noah|coauthors=|title=Don't Miss: Carlos Mencia|pages=|publisher=NPR|date=2006-06-12|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5478891|accessdate=2010-03-18}}</ref> The name appearing on his birth certificate is "Ned Arnel Mencía", although Mencia has said that out of respect for his biological father he went by the Holness name anyway, and was known as "Ned Holness" until he was eighteen years old.<ref name="Menciastories" />
Mencia was raised [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Kozlowski|first=Carl|url=http://www.relevantmagazine.com/culture/film/blog/20931-qaa-carlos-mencia|title=Q&A: Carlos Mencia|work=[[Relevant Magazine]]|quote =|date=|accessdate=2010-06-26}}</ref> in [[East Los Angeles (region)|East Los Angeles]], [[California]] by his aunt Consuelo and uncle Pablo Mencia. By his own admission, staying out of trouble was difficult while growing up, but with the help of his family he excelled in school and stayed out of [[gangs]]. He majored in [[electrical engineering]] at [[California State University, Los Angeles]], but left early to pursue a career in [[comedy]] after a successful performance at an [[open mic]] night at [[The Laugh Factory]]. He has an older brother named Joseph Mencia who often appeared on ''[[Mind of Mencia]]''.
==Career== Mencia was a quick success at such venerated LA stand-up venues as [[The Comedy Store]] and The L.A. Cabaret. This led to appearances on ''[[The Arsenio Hall Show]]'' and ''Buscando Estrellas,'' where he attained the title "International Comedy Grand Champion." Then, in 1994, Mencia was chosen to host [[Home Box Office|HBO's]] [[latino]] comedy showcase ''Loco Slam.''
Mencia followed up ''Loco Slam'' by hosting ''Funny is Funny!'' on [[Galavisión (USA)|Galavision]] in 1998. He would continue to do [[stand-up comedy|stand-up]], including a very successful tour in 2001 with [[Freddy Soto]] and [[Pablo Francisco]], "The Three Amigos." Mencia also did two half-hour specials on HBO, the second of which won him a [[CableACE Award]] for ''Best Stand-Up Comedy Special.'' After the release of his first comedy album by Warner Records, ''Take A Joke America,'' Mencia performed his break-out performance on ''[[Comedy Central Presents]]'' in 2002.
By the time his career began to take off in the early 2000s, Mencia was also working as an actor doing guest appearances in the television shows ''[[Moesha]]'' and ''[[The Shield]],'' and starring in the film ''Outta Time'' and the animated show ''[[The Proud Family]].''
===''Mind of Mencia''=== {{Main|Mind of Mencia}} In March 2005, Comedy Central announced Mencia's own half-hour comedy show, ''[[Mind of Mencia]]''. The show mixed Mencia's stand up comedy with [[sketch comedy]], much like [[Dave Chappelle]]'s ''[[Chappelle's Show]]''. The show achieved moderate success in its first season and was brought back for a second season in the spring of 2006, becoming Comedy Central’s second highest rated program behind ''[[South Park]]''.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | year = | url = http://www.comedycentral.com/press/press_releases/2006/071206_mencia_thirdseason_pickup.jhtml | title = COMEDY CENTRAL DELVES DEEPER INTO THE "MIND OF MENCIA" AND ORDERS THIRD SEASON | work = | publisher = Comedy Central | accessdate = 2006-10-21}}</ref> It was brought back for a third season that summer before being cancelled in 2008. ''Mind of Mencia'' was produced by Nedlos, a [[portmanteau]] of Mencia's birth name and the name he took prior to naturalizing in the US.
===Other work=== Mencia is sometimes a guest on the [[Opie and Anthony]] radio show on [[XM Satellite Radio]] and [[CBS Radio]]. He took part in the first [[Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus Comedy Tour (2006)|Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus Comedy Tour]] in 2006. In 2002 he performed on "Comedy Central Presents."
Mencia starred in a [[Super Bowl XLI]] commercial for [[Bud Light]]. In November 2009, Mencia began appearing commercials for a weight-loss product called Belly Burner, which he has claimed to have used personally.<ref name="imdbtriv">[[IMDB]] page: "[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0578788/bio Carlos Mencia: Trivia]."</ref>
Carlos Mencia is currently on a 2011 stand up comedy tour, including dates at the Improv in Schaumburg, IL on June 24th and 25th, and ending in Las Vegas at Treasure Island on Friday, September 16, 2011. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://khitschicago.radio.com/2011/06/24/carlos-mencia-stops-in-studio-with-eddie-jobo/ |title=Carlos Mencia Stops In Studio With Eddie & Jobo}}</ref>
In 2012, Carlos Mencia stated in an interview that he wished to adopt a less angry persona as his success had made his on-stage anger seem disingenuous. <ref>http://www.marcoislandflorida.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20120531/MARCOENTERTAINMENT/305310027/1188/Video-almost-killed-comedy-star-Carlos-Mencia-?odyssey=mod|newswell|text|Home|p</ref>
Mencia is the co-owner of the restaurant chain [[Maggie Rita's]].<ref name="Sandler">Sandler, Eric. "[http://houston.eater.com/archives/2012/07/06/maggie-ritas-takes-over-three-ninfas-locations.php Three Ninfa's Locations Replaced by Maggie Rita's]." ''Houston [[Eater (website)|Eater]]''. Friday July 6, 2012.</ref>
==Personal life== Mencia lives with his wife, Amy, in the Los Angeles area of [[California]]. They have one child, Lucas Pablo Mencia.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/technology/local/profiles/chi-carlos-mencia-snoop,0,4905309.story | work=Chicago Tribune | first=Nina | last=Metz | title=Got a yen for foot cheese? Stop by Carlos Mencia's}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
==Criticism== Mencia has been criticized for both his stand-up act and his television show, perhaps most notably from other comedians.<ref name="wsj11510">''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' article: "[http://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/01/15/why-some-comics-arent-laughing-at-jay-leno-essay/ Why Some Comics Aren’t Laughing at Jay Leno]".</ref> In 2006, ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'' named Mencia as the 12th worst comic of all time.<ref name="maxim">''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'' article: "[http://www.maxim.com/tv/lists/43869/worst-comedians-all-time.html The Worst Comedians of All Time]."</ref><ref name="rcr">''River City Reader'' article: "[http://www.rcreader.com/news/controlling-the-beast-carlos-mencia/ Controlling the Beast: Carlos Mencia, at the Adler Theatre November 10]."</ref> A 2010 ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' article noted that Mencia, along with [[Dane Cook]] and [[Jay Leno]], were three of the most hated popular stand-ups by fellow comedians.<ref name="wsj11510" /> In May 2009, ''[[Cracked (magazine)|Cracked]]'' listed 25 of the comic's actual [[Twitter]] posts that they considered to be unintentionally funny.<ref name="cracked">''[[Cracked (magazine)|Cracked]]'' article: "[http://www.cracked.com/blog/a-special-look-at-carlos-mencias-twitter Carlos Mencia’s Twitter: 25 Posts Too Unfunny to be Stolen]."</ref>
===Accusations of plagiarism=== In 2005, comedian [[Joe Rogan]] wrote a post on his website publicly accusing Mencia of being a [[Plagiarism|plagiarist]], alleging that Mencia [[joke thievery|stole jokes]] from a number of comedians.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rogan|first=Joe|authorlink=Joe Rogan|url=http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/92|title=Carlos Mencia is a weak minded joke thief.|publisher=JoeRogan.com|date=2005-09-27|accessdate=2006-09-05}}</ref> On February 10, 2007, Rogan confronted Mencia on stage at the [[Comedy Store]] on Sunset and continued his allegations of plagiarism. Rogan posted a video of the altercation with audio and video clips from other comedians including [[George Lopez]], Reverend Bob Levy, [[Bobby Lee]] and Ari Shaffir, among others.<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070215/ENTERTAIN/70215009 Joe Rogan and Carlos Mencia face off at comedy club] [[Times-Herald Record]]</ref> Rogan has also posted audio and video clips of Mencia's interviews and joke routines being compared to those of other comedians on his [[blog]].<ref>[http://www.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment/movies/orl-carlos07oct13,0,2650548.story Carlos Mencia conquers comedy and now eyes the cinema] OrlandoSentinel.com</ref><ref>Rogan Joe. [http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/92 "Carlos Mencia is a weak minded joke thief"], joerogan.net, September 27, 2005</ref>
George Lopez has accused Mencia of plagiarizing his material. In an interview on ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'', Lopez accused Mencia of plagiarizing 13 minutes of his material in Mencia's [[HBO]] special. He also claimed he had a physical altercation with Mencia over the alleged plagiarism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.www.ucdadvocate.com/media/storage/paper538/news/2007/05/02/BonusBytes/Is.Carlos.Mencia.A.Thief-2891990.shtml|author=Goldyn, Debra|title=Is Carlos Mencia a thief?|work=Advocate|publisher=[[University of Colorado at Denver]]|date=2007-05-02|accessdate=2007-05-14}}</ref> The only joke that Lopez has publicly specified was stolen and used on Mencia's HBO special was a [[Taco Bell]] joke. Comedian Ted Sarnowski countered this claim, stating that the joke he performed on radio in 1988 was later taken and used without permission by Lopez, the radio station's resident comic. Sarnowski claims to have given Mencia permission to use the joke, yet Lopez later began referring to Mencia as a "thief" over the joke Lopez allegedly plagiarized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacitybeat.com/article.php?id=5264&IssueNum=199|author=CARL Kozlowski, Carl|title=Carlos Mencia Just Said That|work=|publisher=Los Angeles CityBeat|date=2007-03-29|accessdate=2007-07-14|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070920201944/http://www.lacitybeat.com/article.php?id=5264&IssueNum=199|archivedate=September 20, 2007}}</ref><ref name="claim of copyright">{{cite web|url=http://techdirt.com/articles/20070215/230046.shtml|author=Mike Masnick, Carl|title=Carlos Mencia Claims Copyright Infringement On Comedian Who Accuses Mencia Of Stealing Jokes|date=2008-04-28|accessdate=2008-04-28}}</ref><ref name="Joe Rogan Vs Carlos Mencia">{{cite web|url=http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/110|author=Rogan, Joe|title=Joe Rogan VS Carlos Mencia, ONSTAGE VIDEO|date=2008-04-28|accessdate=2008-04-28}}</ref>
Mencia has also been accused of stealing a routine from [[Bill Cosby]]. In his special, ''No Strings Attached'', Mencia performs a bit about a father who spends years training his son for a career as a [[American football|football]] player, only to see the son say "I love you, Mom!" at his moment of televised victory. Cosby performed a very similar bit in his concert film ''[[Bill Cosby: Himself]]'' and wrote briefly on the subject in his book ''[[Fatherhood (book)|Fatherhood]]''. Mencia told the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' that he had never seen the film but regretted the similarities between his and Cosby's jokes.<ref name=FunnyLosAngeles>{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/1309037121.html?dids=1309037121:1309037121&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+24%2C+2007&author=Robert+W.+Welkos&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&edition=&startpage=A.1&desc=COLUMN+ONE%3B+Funny%2C+that+was+my+joke%3B+It%27s+no+laughing+matter+when+comedians+feel+someone+has+stolen+their+stuff.+A+generation+ago+it+was+rare%2C+but+the+old+code+is+breaking+down.|title=Funny, that was my joke|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|author=Welkos, Robert W.|date=2007-07-24|accessdate=2008-05-04}}</ref>
Mencia's alleged plagiarism was satirized on the April 8, 2009 episode of ''[[South Park]]'' entitled "[[Fishsticks (South Park)|Fishsticks]]" in which Mencia takes credit for a joke that somebody else had written. When faced with the prospect of being assaulted he admits "I took credit for it because I'm not actually funny!.... I just take jokes and repackage them with a Mexican accent!" The character is then killed by [[Kanye West]].<ref>{{cite episode|title=Fishsticks|episodelink=Fishsticks (South Park)|series=South Park|serieslink=South Park|airdate=2009-04-08|season=13|number=5}}</ref> Joe Rogan and friend Ari Shaffir were delighted with the treatment of Mencia on the show and even commented on Rogan's blog about it.
Mencia also addressed the issue of plagiarism in two hour-long interviews with fellow comic [[Marc Maron]] on his podcast, ''[[WTF with Marc Maron]]'', in May 2010.<ref>http://wtfpod.libsyn.com/episode_75_carlos_mencia</ref><ref>http://wtfpod.libsyn.com/episode_76_willie_barcena_steve_trevino_carlos_responds</ref>
In 2011, Mencia stated in an interview that he had been in therapy due to accusations of plagiarism.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/27/arts/television/carlos-mencia-new-territory-on-comedy-central.html?pagewanted=all|title=A Comedian's Act Is Leaner But Not Meaner|last=Keller|first=Joel|date=27 November 2011|work=The New York Times|page=27|accessdate=31 July 2012}}</ref>
===Hurricane Katrina remarks=== In February 2009, Mencia was dropped from the [[Krewe of Orpheus]]' celebrity lineup for [[New Orleans Mardi Gras]], citing inappropriate comments he made in the aftermath of [[Hurricane Katrina]]. Mencia remarked during his stand up: “I’m glad Hurricane Katrina happened. It taught us an important lesson: Black people can’t swim.”<ref>[http://www.wdsu.com/mardigras/18653787/detail.html#- "Orpheus Drops Carlos Mencia As Monarch"] WDSU.com. February 5, 2009.</ref>
==Filmography== * ''[[In Living Color]]'' (TV), playing a Valet in episode six of season two, (1990) * ''[[Moesha]]'' (TV), playing Carlos in the episode "Life Imitating Art," (1999) * ''[[The Proud Family]]'' (TV), starring as Felix (voice) (2001–2005) * ''[[The Shield]]'' (TV) playing Gabo in the episode "Two Days of Blood," (2002) * ''[[Outta Time]]'' (2002), playing "Juancho" * ''[[29 Palms (film)|29 Palms]]'' (2002), playing "The Comedian" * ''[[Mind of Mencia]]'' (TV) Host (2005–2008) * ''[[Drawn Together]]'' (TV) playing the King of Mexico (voice) in the episode "[[Mexican't Buy Me Love]]", (2006) * ''[[Farce of the Penguins]]'' (2007) * ''[[The Heartbreak Kid (2007 film)|The Heartbreak Kid]]'' (2007), playing Uncle Tito * ''[[MADtv]]'' (2007), playing himself * ''[[Our Family Wedding]]'' (2010) * New Territory <ref name=websitebio>{{cite web |url=http://carlosmencia.com/bio/|title=Carlos Bio |author= |date= |work= |publisher=carlosmencia.com |accessdate=1 May 2012}} </ref>
Not including his comedy specials for HBO and Comedy Central, Mencia has also appeared on ''[[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]]'', and hosted ''Loco Slam'' in 1994, ''Latino Laugh Festival'' in 1997, ''Funny is Funny!'' in 1998, and ''Uncensored Comedy: That's Not Funny'' in 2003.
==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''Take a Joke America'' (2001) * ''America Rules'' (2002) * ''Unmerciful'' (2003)
===Albums and DVDs=== * ''Not for the Easily Offended'' (2003) * ''Down to the Nitty Gritty'' (2004) * ''This is Carlos Mencia'' (2006) * ''No Strings Attached'' (2006) * ''The Best of Funny is Funny'' (2007) * ''Performance Enhanced'' (2008) * ''Mind of Mencia Season 1'' (2006) * ''Mind of Mencia Season 2'' (2007) * ''Mind of Mencia Season 3'' (2007)
